Posts.Content: Hi Kristen, Thanks for asking,I'm sure she would appreciate being thought of. Well she had her 2nd treatment Tuesday,this week, and she's been nauseous(sp) every since . There are too many drugs out there for her to suffer through this, she needs to let the doctor know.She lost her hair last weekend,You know that's always traumatic .She's trying to keep her chin up-her counts have been such she did have her 2nd treatment ,I hope they continue to do so.She's lost a little more weight ,the fluid is all gone now which may be part of the loss.She's doing well though considering all of the challenges. I hope You are doing well-haven't seen You post in awhile.Thank You for remembering my Sister-God Bless You! Merry Christmas!!! (((HUGS)))

Posts.Title: mssue

Posts.Content: I copied and pasted this email to share with all of You-I found it most interesting-different views of coping with the things in our life...Hope You Enjoy... Your scars are beautiful. They are the brushstrokes in the masterpiece that is your life. Ancient legend tells of the powerful Amazons, a race of one-breasted female warriors. These fierce fighting women, known for their skill as archers, underwent voluntary mastectomies so their breasts would not interfere with their aim. Their very survival depended upon the radical surgery. Legend also tells of the Scythian culture in which women were expected to fight alongside the men. A mastectomy of the right breast was performed on female infants to prevent weakening of the pectoral muscle on that side. This ensured the girls would be able to brandish a sword with power and skill. Scholars debate whether there is any truth behind these popular stories, but Ã?? true or not Ã?? the tales provide us with a thought-provoking way in which to reframe the way we see our scars. Instead of looking at the scars on our bodies as reminders of illness and weakness, we could look at them as evidence that illness and weakness were removed from our bodies, making us more powerful than we were before. We could take pride in our scars because they are proof of battles we have fought and won. They speak of our courage and resolve. They tell the stories of our lives. As we age, our faces and bodies naturally develop lines and wrinkles in addition to the scars that result from accidents and surgeries. Instead of fighting the lines and wrinkles with cosmetic surgeries and hiding our battle scars as if they are shameful or embarrassing, why not look at them as evidence of the rich collection of experiences that have shaped our characters over time and made us who we are today? Each of us is a miracle, and each of us is a masterpiece of the Creator. One-of-a-kind. No two alike. A singular work of art full of power and promise. Rejoice in all of your brushstrokes! Heavenly Father, help me to remember that I am Your creation and that everything You have created is perfect and beautiful. Amen -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Roger and Kathy Cawthon The Cancer Crusade

Posts.Title: Sharing and Living

Posts.Content: Hi Kristen, Actually her doctor suggested that we have our daughters tested for mutated genes,her daughter is 19 mine is 14.You see my Aunt(Mothers side)had breast cancer,Mom Ovarian,Sister Cervical,me Breast,now my sister again with ovarian.I assume I would have to go back to the onocology doctor for testing wouldn't I? I am glad that Your Sister's cancer has been caught early if that's what it is.I didn't know there was a her2nu website,You'll have to educate me.I am in menopause,I'm not really sure how it's classified,You know perimenopause or what, but I haven't had any spotting or anything since February 2005.They told me that the chemo I recieved would put me there. One thing that kind of concerns me is that when I had my yearly check-up(pap-smear) I had a different Doctor this year,my old one retired.My old one upon finding out about my Mother and all did a vaginal ultra sound to check my ovaries.It's kind of scary that they have such a hard time ,until it's already progressed to later stages,of detecting ovarian cancer.My new Doctor,even though I said something about it to him,didn't seemed concerned and did not do the test.This was in September 2005,now my sister is dealing with that exact thing.I think I might find a different OBGYN.I just finished reading an article on MSN that said Breast Cancer survivors are at a higher risk of developing another cancer elsewhere in the body caused from treatments-Bummer-I can't remember it all,You can go to www.msn.com it's there this morning(12/24/05). let me know You thoughts. Smile and have fun today-

Posts.Title: mssue

Posts.Content: Hi Donna S, Congratulations on Your Anniversary!!! Sometimes I find it difficult to figure out if it is muscle ,nerve or bone pain.Sometimes the pain is not actually where the problem is- my pains like to travel LOL they stay on the fast track some days -then other days I'm fine.My PT made a point of letting me know that chemotherapy-no particular one-can cause peripheral nerve damage.I have trouble with my legs going numb,can't stand or walk for very long,they prescribed nuerontin about 1800 mg daily - I must admit it does seem to help prolonging the times I can stand or sit-I'm still in therapy though. Maybe You could talk to Your regular Doctor and maybe they can possibly refer You to physical therapy- aquatic therapy was great the water is very warm and soothing,and the exercises are so easy,I couldn't continue traveling to the center where the pool was(about a 50 mile round trip)but my local hospital has some wonderful Physical Therapist. It's just an idea -I know how it feels to get all the test and then they come back negative-this is great in it's self -but then You still don't know what the problem is-we just have to keep searching.My thoughts and prayers are with You-let us know what You find out. (((HUGS)))

Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi, While it is good to be aware of your body, getting use to a changing one takes time and practice.At your age your body is still changing but if you will go see a gynocologist and get a physical(a pap smear and a breast exam) they should be able to give you plenty of information and answer your questions -they also have literature in their offices on doing self breast exams. Alot of people have introverted nipples and never have a problem,but if you have never had a check up maybe it is time,besides you are never to young to learn what to be aware of concerning your health.I am sending you my best wishes and prayers too! {hugs}

Posts.Title: Help me. Do I need to get checked for breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi, I realize and understand the impact this has on everyone,Your Mum is probably afraid too! As difficult as it is the more information she has, the better decisions she will be able to make to get her through this.Have they already done a biopsy?There is alot of information out there ,not only for the patient but for the caregivers too. Depending on the stage of the cancer(this is usually determined by the biopsy) and armed with info. she and her health care team can decide what will be the best course of action to take. None of it is easy-Question though, will she be having reconstructive surgery done also?I bring this up because it can be done during the same procedure(mastectomy)and they can do skin sparing surgery which would probably be better for her in the long run.Some people wait to get the procedure done and some never have it done,I'm in the latter group.There are alot of different things going on now ,making it easy to get confused.It would be a good idea if when she goes to the Doctor someone accompanies her,in this whirlwind we are scared and anxious and don't always get everything-writing down any questions she may have will help things go smoother too.It's a life altering experience,some good and some not so good, but it can usually be managed with the help and understanding of Family,friends,co-workers and a good health care team. It's ok to cry and be upset-stomp Your feet and have a fit,You'll feel better when You get it out.Keep the lines of communication open,alot of times just knowing someone is there is a comfort in itself.My thoughts and prayers are with You and Your Family. God Bless You!

Posts.Title: Muscle Pain almost two years after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Linda, I am not really sure why they would want to check it again in 2 months if they thought it was nothing.For myself ,when I had a lump, it came up in my right breast -(they say it doesn't happen like this) but-when I was putting on my gown that night I had a really bad pain in my R breast,where the pain was is where a lump popped up.I went and had it checked by the Doctor,then went for the Mammogram-the lump on the R side was a cyst - what they found on the left side, which You couldn't feel, was cancer. Who'd a thought it . If I were You I would follow up on it until I was satisfied that I was okay, then keep check on a regular bases. Keep us posted . Hugs

Posts.Title: Found out today that my mum has breast cancer

Posts.Content: Just thought I'd drop a line to let You know I just returned from Mississippi ,being with my Sister for her surgery.Everything went well those first shots of chemo worked and shrunk down the tumors,they think they got all of the cancer,now she is suppose to have 3 more rounds of chemo and a years worth of Taxol. I'm still having a hard time with several things like my Sister looks to have aged 15 years,I can't believe it,I know people in my family don't age well but that much change so suddenly???I felt terrible and I know it didn't make her feel any better when she finally got her room at the hospital almost every nurse that came in thought I was her daughter,there is only 7 years difference between us, I think word finally got around and that all stopped.She has been through soooo much, she hasn't had time to greive for her Husband yet.By the way 10 days before her surgery was due her husband of 28 years had a massive heart attack and died he was only 50. And to top it all off they look to be at a stand still with the clean up of Hurricane Katrina. I parked down at the beach and just cried--there are still people living in tents,some have fema trailers others don't -what few restuarants are open close at 2 or 3 in the afternoon because they don't have people to work.Alot of the trees that were left along the beach still look like they've been ravished with cotton and debri,all of the beautiful old homes that survived Camille back in the sixties are gone now.The beaches are still full of debri ,water and sand and can You believe they are still finding bodies. I am soooo glad to be back home(NC), but sad at lifes circumstances.Please remember to pray for all the people down there that everyone else seems to have forgotten. God Bless You All (((HUGS)))

Posts.Content: HAPPY MOTHERS DAY, BEST WISHES TO ALL OF YOU-WHETHER YOUR CHILDREN ARE TWO LEGGED OR FOUR.MAY YOUR DAY BE FILLED WITH LOTS OF LAUGHTER,PLEASANT SURPRISES AND BLESSINGS FROM ABOVE. STAY STRONG,HAVE FAITH AND ENJOY THE BEAUTY OF YOUR INNER LIGHT , TO BURN BRIGHT AS A BEACON IN THE NIGHT, GIVING WAY TO YOUR HEART STRINGS TO PLAY A WONDERFUL MELODY TO CARRY YOU THROUGH THE DAY. YOU ARE ALL VERY SPECIAL AND UNIQUE.LET NO ONE TELL YOU ANY DIFFERENT. MAY GOD BLESS YOU ALL TODAY AND ALWAYS

Posts.Title: Happy Mothers Day!!

Posts.Content: Hi! I'm new here-hope I'm doing this right .History-diagnost on Aug 29th 2003 found lump in right breast-after mamo suspicious calcifications they thought in left breast-right side was just a cyst.After needle biopsy found it to be cancer,infiltrating ductal carcinoma, early stage 1, 2 to 21/2 cm had mastectomy bilateral on the left side removed about 16 lymp nodes all negative her-2 neu+.Since mastecomy no radiation,with four rounds of a/c.Finished up in January of 2004.Have kept all follow-up appointments.Still have rib pain al the way across the front of the rib cage,sometimes my entire rib cage hurts so bad I can't lay down-they have done bone scans and a ct scan to no avail.This is I guess something I must live with I guess since there seems to be no evidence of anything showing up.Right now my main concern is my remaining breast.About two and a half weeks ago during an intimate moment with my husband I started having severe pain in my breast-since then I have really sharp pains -it's not just the nipple but about half way up my breast,it doesn't look any different I can't feel any lumps-But it's so sore I can't stand to touch it,now that is constant,the stabbing pains just come and go.Is this normal ,does it just go away?I've got alot of other issues to top this of ---I lost my job last month and I'm waiting for my Cobra to be finalized so that I have ins. again.My gynocologist retired in Dec.04-my family doctor had an accident and know I hear he may not be coming back to the office. I guess my basic question is this something that happens to everyone -can it wait-should I be concerned.Sorry to go on like this-hope this makes sense.If some one could shed some light on this I would really appreciate your help.Thanks for your time. Sue

Posts.Title: Very painful breast

Posts.Content: Well I have 2 Dr.'s appointments on Monday-I went to the hospital this morning for blood work-I had them take an extra vile in case anybody else needed some for testing.They have a really hard time getting blood from me I can't stand it when I have to get stuck three or four times,especially when they have to do it more than once a week. Yes my breast is still very tender-I just hope they don't make it worse by poke around it.As long as everything is okay though I can deal with it.I'll keep You posted. How is everyone else holding up?Hope everything is well with You Guys.Take care ! Thanks!

Posts.Title: Very painful breast

Posts.Content: Well since I last posted,I've seen my cardiologist,everything seems to be improving-my cholesterol is down to 207(almost normal) my triglycerides are down to 525(still alittle high) .I will double the fish oil I'm taking ,along with the other regiment of supplements.Go back in 3 months to find out if it's working if not going back on Gemfibrizol(sp).I feel pretty good about that visit.I found a great MD,she's new to the office where my old DR was,I really like her.We've scheduled a mammogram and chest x-ray for April 6th.She put me on 800mg of Ibuprofen 3x daily for pain.She couldn't feel anything in my breast either-but to be on the safe side the test with be taken. Thanks for all of you're support.I really appreciate all of Your time and Your kindness.Have a wonderful day!!!

Posts.Title: Very painful breast

Posts.Content: Oh my gosh! I've been telling my Husband for over a year now that my eyesight wasn't as good as it used to be.Jan. of 04 was my last treatment,it had gotten to the point that I couldn't read the menu screen on the TV much less read what anything was about.My daughter or husband would have to read it for me -it was soooo blurry,I would get so aggravated that I would get up and stand in front of the TV so I wouldn't bother everybody else ,like they could see through me-ha ha! I finally two weeks ago while my daughter was getting her annual exam I ask if he could see me too.Results - near sighted.Man I feel so dumb I have this antique mirror ,it has this hazy hue to it ,right ,well it's not quite as bad as I thought now that I have my new glasses- Wow I 'm still amazed with these new things,I'll look at something then pull the glasses down and put 'em back everything is so much clearer,I can even see where I need to dust Guess there's no more excuses huh. I still think it was the chemo ,I had 20/20 before it.This is the first time I've seen anyone post on the subject.Everyone kept telling me aw your just getting older-ah ha! Maybe --maybe not. Glad I'm not the only one----Thanks You Guys.Keep 'em posting!

Thanks for your input.I've never heard of this costochdritis-but I will research it now .After so long of being in pain and no one able to tell you why you begin to feel like a hypocondriac. Hopefully my cobra will be in effect within the next few weeks.I guess I'm going to have to start looking for new physicians,it's like starting all over again.But I know things could be alot worse so I'm not complaining. Hopefully like you guys said maybe it's just a nerve or something in my breast ,it surely is awfully sore though. The pain in my ribs have been going on so long I finally came to the conclusion that it was something I had to live with forever.I'm going to search the web now for costochdritis ,see if symptoms are the same.You have no idea how that would make me feel if I could find a way to relieve this pain--Thank You Both so much. God Bless You! Sue age-44

Posts.Title: Very painful breast

Posts.Content: I'm in the USA,North Carolina.I found out today that the ins co has activated my prescriptions renewal-have to wait 36 hours for dr visits-go figure .Anyway I'm very glad that part is finally coming together.I'm calling the Nurse at the Hospital here ,where I recieved treatments to see if she can recommend a good Dr.-she always did what she could to make things as easy as possible when I was going thru treatments. I've looked up costchondritis-two things about what I've read bothers me-first ,all of this time ,since surgery Sept. 2003,I've had pain not just on the surgery side(left) but also on the rightside-I kept telling all of the doctors I thought it was my Liver -they said no probably gallstones-finally after lots of complaining on my part they did an ultra sound of my Liver,this was around Nov. 04.They said I had a fatty liver,okay so what do I do about it and how did it get like this?I'll try to keep it as short as possible-about two weeks before I diagnosed I was extremely exhausted-went for check up,my cholesterol and triglycerides were out of the roof-chol-275/tri-700.They were worried about heart attack,right,then when diagnosed with cancer everything else got put on the back burner.The cancer was more important then.After the Liver test was done,the fatty liver was due to my cholesterol and triglycerides being so high for so long-my.Last visit with my onocologist she ordered a ct scan,chest ,abdomen and pelvic.Found a cyst on my Liver supposed to have the ct done again in about two months.They said the cyst are common in most people and usually found when looking for something else and shouldn't cause any health risk. That's my history in a nut shell-Right now after reading about costchondritis if i read it correctly-if you have problems with your liver it's harder to treat,is this correct? And that it usually only last about 2 weeks/or a lifetime.I'm still not sure what test they can do to be able to determine if that is the reason for pain.I myself try to look at things and do a proccess of elimination. I don't know -I wanted to keep this short-but I don't think I accomplished that -HA! HA! Sorry! I will get things worked out -I'm eternally grateful to You Ladies for Your time ,patience and experience.God Bless You All!!!!!

Posts.Content: I'm in the USA,North Carolina.I found out today that the ins co has activated my prescriptions renewal-have to wait 36 hours for dr visits-go figure .Anyway I'm very glad that part is finally coming together.I'm calling the Nurse at the Hospital here ,where I recieved treatments to see if she can recommend a good Dr.-she always did what she could to make things as easy as possible when I was going thru treatments. I've looked up costchondritis-two things about what I've read bothers me-first ,all of this time ,since surgery Sept. 2003,I've had pain not just on the surgery side(left) but also on the rightside-I kept telling all of the doctors I thought it was my Liver -they said no probably gallstones-finally after lots of complaining on my part they did an ultra sound of my Liver,this was around Nov. 04.They said I had a fatty liver,okay so what do I do about it and how did it get like this?I'll try to keep it as short as possible-about two weeks before I diagnosed I was extremely exhausted-went for check up,my cholesterol and triglycerides were out of the roof-chol-275/tri-700.They were worried about heart attack,right,then when diagnosed with cancer everything else got put on the back burner.The cancer was more important then.After the Liver test was done,the fatty liver was due to my cholesterol and triglycerides being so high for so long-my.Last visit with my onocologist she ordered a ct scan,chest ,abdomen and pelvic.Found a cyst on my Liver supposed to have the ct done again in about two months.They said the cyst are common in most people and usually found when looking for something else and shouldn't cause any health risk. That's my history in a nut shell-Right now after reading about costchondritis if i read it correctly-if you have problems with your liver it's harder to treat,is this correct? And that it usually only last about 2 weeks/or a lifetime.I'm still not sure what test they can do to be able to determine if that is the reason for pain.I myself try to look at things and do a proccess of elimination. I don't know -I wanted to keep this short-but I don't think I accomplished that -HA! HA! Sorry! I will get things worked out -I'm eternally grateful to You Ladies for Your time ,patience and experience.God Bless You All!!!!!

Posts.Title: Very painful breast

Posts.Content: Genes Discovered That May Predict Breast Cancer Spread to Lungs -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Finding could one day help doctors better tailor therapy for patients, study says By Kathleen Doheny, HealthDay Reporter Today's Health News WEDNESDAY, July 27 (HealthDay News) -- Researchers have identified a set of genes that seems to predict if breast cancer will spread to the lungs and how serious the disease will be. The finding could eventually help doctors to predict whose disease will become aggressive and spread, and potentially help them to better target treatments. The lungs and the bones are frequent sites for cancer that spreads from the breast. And cancer that spreads from the breast to organs such as the lungs accounts for the majority of breast cancer-related deaths, research has shown. "We are the first to identify a clinically relevant set of genes that can predict metastases [spread] of breast cancer to the lungs," said study co-author Gaorav Gupta, a graduate student and researcher at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. A report on the finding appears in the July 28 issue of Nature. The researchers began with a set of cancer cell lines from 82 human breast cancer tumors. "We used a mouse model to mimic metastases," Gupta said. "We take these cells and inject them into a special type of mouse that allows you to inject human cells into them. We allowed lung metastases to form. We took out the lung metastases and took the cells and asked, 'What is special about these cells that will allow them to create the metastases?' " To answer the question, the researchers used a "microarray" technique that allowed them to look at 22,000 genes all at once. Then they identified the genes that created the cancer spread to the lungs, and then put the genes back into the original cells to verify they were responsible. Then they took another look at the human tumors. "We asked, of these 82 tumors, which ones expressed our genes [identified as those responsible for the spread]. We found a subgroup that expressed the genes and these patients were much more likely to develop lung metastasis." Next, said Gupta, the research team hopes to repeat the findings in a larger group of patients, "to be certain this isn't just something unique about the cohort we selected." If patients with these genes can be identified, the next avenue of research would be to figure out if there are specific drugs that could prevent the lung tumors from forming. Certain "inhibitor" drugs have already been shown to suppress the genes identified in the new study, Gupta said. William C. Phelps, scientific program director of the research department for the American Cancer Society, praised the new study, saying, "Being able to identify a patient with a higher probability of developing metastasis would be of tremendous importance in terms of managing these patients." The severity and course of cancer, even the same type, can be very different from patient to patient, Phelps said. "One of the decisions to struggle with is what [treatment] to give to which patients," he said. "Obviously, if you know cells in a particular tumor will be more likely to spread to the lung or bone, you would treat these patients more aggressively." The identification of the gene pattern is a first step, he said. "If we can identify those genes, the next step may be to target the genes for therapy to prevent the spread of the tumors."

Posts.Content: Hi All, This is off of the subject but I felt the need to express my concern for my family living in Gulfport,Ms and Long Beach,Ms.My Brother and his wife were able to evacuate with some neighbors to Northern Alabama,my 2 Sisters and their Families aren't as fortunate , with a combination of funds and lack of dependable transportation-they are going to be there to weather this monster of a Hurricane-I have been crying off and on all day-We lived in Gulfport when Camille came thru in 1969-we evacuated North-my Dad stayed behind -but after everything was over he said he'd never do that again our house was in shambles-the large back porch we had was gone-no food -water-electricity I was about to turn 9 yrs old August 21st-Camille hit August 17th.There was so much despare-looting-push and shove.It was a nightmare I'll never forget that-the thought of my Family going through this again is so scary-I'm sitting in NC wishing there was something I could do-but the only thing I can do now is pray-will You guys remember to pray not only for my family but for all of those who cannot afford to evacuate for what ever their circumstance are. I know this is off the subject but I had to interject since Katrina had already been brought up.

Posts.Content: Hi Jill, It seems that it is a safety measure especially the altering of the 2 test.I'm glad You have a Doctor that is keeping a close check on You-alot of people aren't as forunate.We all know that early detection is key to staying on top of this disease and keeping it at bay.And yes anytime a person is diagnosed with cancer the chances of reoccurance are greater than in someone who has not been dx'd. I didn't realize until very recently 2 to 3 wks, that there is such a thing as Kidney cancer.My husband just passed a kidney stone and going through all the testing,xray,ct and such they found a mass in the same kidney the stone was in-mind You, he just passed a stone a year ago-there was no mass there 1 year ago.Anyway from what I've read for the size of the mass it would be considered a stage 2 (w/kidney it's staged between a 1-4) although it looks like it hasn't spread we won't know for sure until after the surgery this Friday,they will be removing his entire kidney.If it hasn't spread, with this kind of cancer there is no other treatments,no chemo or anything as long as it hasn't spread.So wow surgery can cure it although since he has had it now there is a chance he can have it again.I - we just keep praying to get through this and for his comfort -I hear it is a very painful surgery.Oh and by the way if he hadn't been passing this kidney stone they would not have found the mass-they found it accidentally-it would have been there growing,because like most cancers we aren't even aware they are there until they start producing symptoms which is usually in the later stages with poorer outcomes . Well You keep us posted , my thoughts and prayers are with You. :P I am feeling alot of different emotions this week,but for today -my birthday I'll take and keep praying. ((hugs))

Posts.Title: MRI and mammogram

Posts.Content: Question? How or what can I do to rebuild my blood vessels or veins? I just returned from getting a CT scan done , I was stuck 4 times before they were able to thread the cathider(sp) through. I had an MRI on Friday 2 sticks, blood work yesterday 3 sticks. My veins keep blowing or collapsing whatever You want to call it. Right now my whole arm is sore-there has to be something I can do to make it better. As bad as it hurt today, I felt sorry for the guy who did the CT scan, he kept apologizing for so many sticks ,it wasn't just him someone else was called in too. The same thing happened the last time I had this test done,same guy then too. I told him it was not his fault, but what could I do to rebuild my veins -the only thing he knew was to hydrate myself well before blood work is drawn-that still wouldn't help in this particular procedure. I have never had this problem before,then again I've never been stuck so much in my life as I have been the last 2 years. I thought that was the reason for having a port put in for treatment, to save my veins. Looking back at it now- the chemo still runs through the veins -so damage still happens. Does anyone have any suggestions, I would really appreciate your input. Thanks, Sue

Posts.Content: Hi, Thanks , I believe if I use all of the suggested methods there should be no problem with sticks. I'll find out the next time , when it's time. Since I last posted I've done a little research and I'm wondering if anyone else might have tried a supplement called Oligomeric Proanthocyanidins or for short OPC's? If so what were the results? From what I've read it's a grape seed extract or pine bark extract. The principal uses of this supplement are strengthening blood vessels,reducing inflammation,hemorrhoids ,edema.I know there is no magic pill but I'm already taking several different supplements that I know have been the reason my cholesterol and tryglicerides(sp) have came down. Because I take an antacid everyday ,as it gets rid of stomach acids, it also deprives my body of some of the B-vitamins it needs and so on.So the supplements have definitely been helping-I try to make sure I'm not taking anything that would counteract with anything else,I do research that before starting. With the OPC's I found that if You are taking blood thinners that it should only be taken under a Doctors supervision. If I can't find enough info. I will ask a pharmacist or Doctor about the effects of a supplement. I know that when I've asked the Doctor about different supplements ,in the past, they really were not very knowledgable about the effects nor the use of them. Something must be working for me though because the proof is in the results. I go back Tuesday for the results of my MRI and CT scan. I'm there with Ya Kristen-waiting. May we both have good results. Thanks everybody for your input I will use Your suggestions when preparing for my next trip to the Doctor. I am going to do more research-if anyone else has used this or knows about it ,the OPC's,let me know. God Bless You All! Sue

If I remember correctly on the Herceptin it is given for 1 year.I didn't have it though,it was after my treatments were complete that they finished the study on Herceptin and found that in women with early stage BC it help reduce the risk of reoccurence,I don't know the percentage,but I'm sure it can be found on the internet. Posts.Content: Dear Dawn, Good Morning,I had read Your post-wasn't really sure how to answer it-thought someone else would pick up on it -since not -I'm repling-as best I can.This site is here because it gives people a chance to vent , ask questions , get other peoples opinion on their particular situation.We all have fears - and we may not always have the right answers but there are alot of good people here with a wealth of information-I don't think anyone is trying to scare anyone-these are real life issues that people are trying to get a handle on.When people are upset,worried,scared-not knowing what to do - they turn here.I for one am so very glad this site is here. I like countless others have had alot of sleepless nights waiting and worrying - being able to access information 24/7 or if nothing else a kind word or a wise word from someone who's been there-then there are 2 Doctors that keep check here too.Now that I've said that-to get to Your painful breast-I too posted a thread on painful breast You are welcome to go back and read the post there-I had a mammogram done it was all clear-I guess I'm in menopause now so I don't have that time anymore but even when I did, I had the same problem with tenderness and swelling too.Before my time I could always tell it was coming,but it seemed like there were times too that they stayed sore for longer periods. That in it's self wasn't condusive to anything except raging harmones. I hate that You are getting so stressed out over everything-One of the best things i think I've learned from all of my experiences is to be patient (with myself),to be kind(to myself) and to love(myself).We must all listen to our bodies-when something doesn't feel quite right - get it checked out-if You have a good Doctor and You trust them - then take those good results to the bank and shrug those worries away-if You aren't so sure get a second or third opinion-until You are satisfied You will find it difficult to have peace of mind. As far as the post You read-don't be so shocked or take everything into Your own soul,everyone has a different experience-just take what You can use and leave the rest behind.My thoughts and prayers are with you.Take it easy and be good to yourself. (((HUGS)))

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I posted an article from MSN from an interview with someone from the Mayo Clinic.Some of it made me go HUMMM! I posted it on the General Cancer Forum.I would like to find out what You all think if you have time,they call it Debunking Cancer Myths,I know I've actually thought of some of this myself. My Mother died from cancer along with lots of other relatives,but my Mother's cancer was found too late.They said it started in her ovaries and spread through out her abdomen,to other organs.She was only checked after I insisted that she go and get a knot checked out that came up on her upper abdomen,we really thought it was hernia,so did the Doctor.When they cut her open they found the cancer ,everywhere.You know people tend to run around like a chicken with their heads cut off when this kind of news hits.Everyone was saying that during surgerybeing opened up the cancer coming in contact w/air caused it to spread.Mind you this didn't come from the Doctor-I'm not really sure where it came from-it was debunked in that article though. That was thirteen years ago,my Mother died 3 wks before my Daughter was born.I've never questioned the coming into air contact subject,my knowledge about cancer its self was really not what I wished it would have been back then. Well maybe I shouldn't go in to deep-I really just would like to know what you think after you read the article.Your input would be greatly appreciated.Thanks! God Bless You!

Posts.Content: Hi Danielle, Glad to hear Your Mom is doing well, I hope it continues. I agree with Nancy , it affects everyone differently. With the A/C it's the adriamicyn that makes your hair come out ,its red in color. Does she have a wig or scarves or hats? Even knowing it's going to happen ,doesn't really make it any easier for most anyway.Alot of people cut their hair really short when it first starts coming out ,for some they have woke up to most of their hair on the pillow -it's still difficult to deal with-but it goes with the territory,we're still living! I'm a little surprised they are already giving her something to boost her white cell count,though I know everyone is different, If I remember correctly,for myself , it was after my second treatment that they gave me Nuelasta(sp). I was given that twiced after 2nd and 3rd treatment. Tell her to listen to her body,when fatigued rest,try and eat more fresh veggies and fruit-and to drink alot of water especially the day of treatment and the next day too,that way she will flush out her system -those chemicals are not something you want lingering in your kindneys nor bladder. I'm so glad you are able to arrange your schedule . Your Mother is very lucky to have you.Don't forget to take care of yourself too! Care Givers get tired too.Stay strong and God Bless You!

Posts.Content: Hi, I myself recently found out I do no qualify for reconstructive surgery-but it is not due to lack of skin.I tried to research different possibilities before I was scheduled to see a surgeon,what I found was that the DIEP is different from the tram flap because the afore mentioned uses muscle tissue.With the DIEP they use skin and fat from your abdominal area to reconstruct the breast-better choice in the long run because 1 your body can't reject itself,where with inplants,they can burst,be rejected and if nothing else have to be replaced in the future,which of course means more surgery. Good luck on your journey-I'd be interested to know how things go for you.Make sure You write down any questions you may have for your Doctor.My thoughts are with You! Best Wishes!

Posts.Content: Hi! Though it might well be something that doesn't happen very often (men w/BC) does not dismiss the fact that it needs prompt attention. I am on the opposite coast from You so I'm not much help with the availability of any surgeons in Your area. While it could possibly turn out to be nothing more than an infection , it could very well be more.Anyone who has dealt with cancer knows that it does not discriminate. With that being said if I were You I would get on the computer find a Hospital,maybe a training hospital if possible, but check out their staff for possible Doctors that specialize in BC and call them,let them know Your concerns and what is going on with You and about Your Mother too! The worst thing that can happen is that they don't have a sooner appt. right-but You will have peace of mind in know that You are covering all bases. I just went in to Genetic Counseling,if I test positive that means that there is a big chance that I passed that mutated gene on to my kids,boys and girls,even if they are never diagnosed with cancer the gene could still be passed on to their children ,my grandchildren. I'm not a Grandmother yet Te!HE! But that is still a concern of mine. Times like this are very taxing on our well being so try to stay as calm as possible, write down Your thoughts and any questions that You want to ask the Doctor and take someone with You, if for nothing else but support.But sometimes when someone else is there with You they might remember something the Doctor said that You may have missed. Let me know how things turn out,these sites are really helpful when You need support,understanding and for answers to questions,they helped me through many sleepless nights. I'll be praying that it's nothing,I'll be thinking about You over this Holiday weekend. I also wanted to mention that if incase it turns out to be the dreaded thing-as far as insurance and all there are also medical trials to check into. Try to enjoy the weekend-we are here if You need us. Hugs

Posts.Content: Okay,since I haven't had a period since February of 2005 but had one a few days ago, lasting 6 days. Started out with spotting but extremely painful cramps,the cramps remained through out and the spotting turned to a light flow.Am I still in menopause? And as for the hot flashes...I have had them for years but awhile ago I started having a flash then getting a chill. Then a constant onslaught of extreme heat. I started looking for some releif, I found Black Cohosh. As far as the Black Cohosh is concerned, I did research and cross referenced it with other meds I'm taking but you know what,in thinking about it, the way ovarian cancer-along with other cancers run in my family my chances of reoccurance are pretty far up there.I think the biggest thing I was looking at was the fact that my BC hormone receptors were negative. So my cancer was not spurred along by hormones but by something else.The hot flashes I was having weren't flashes anymore, more like a ravenous forest fire burning out of control,they would start about 3 in the morning and last until 10 or 11 at night, seeming to get hotter as the days went by. This went on for several weeks,I tried to talk to all of my doctors,reg Doctor,Onocologist,Gynocologist,even told my Orthopedic-EVERYONE shrugged it off as if it were nothing and here I am getting to my breaking point-I had already asked all of them about the Black Cohosh,nobody seemed to care one way or the other or didn't know anything about it -then shrugged it off. It really did give me some releif for awhile, but since having a period I have slacked off and am maybe only taking one a day and actually skipping somedays. Now they are back to 'almost' regular flashes,2 or 3 spells a day.LOL - I can deal with that!!!I can't take the all day ones though,if they come back - I don't know what I'm going to do. What does everyone else do-please tell me I'm not the only one having them like this(the allday ones),please....

Posts.Title: side effects of triptorelin

Posts.Content: Hi Barbara, I am not sure if I can answer all of your questions but I'll try. 1 - You said she is on her 3rd treatment,it really depends on the combination of drugs they are using and everyone is different.My treatments were every three weeks.My hair started coming out around the time for my 2nd treatment. 2 & 3 - There is a thing called a Nadir (sp) period,usually around the second week after the treatment(really depends on the chemo recieved)the white blood counts can drop making you more subseptable to infection.If the counts to get too far out of range they may need to give her something like Neulasta to bring the counts up in order to continue treatments.I had the Neulasta twice it can cause alot of bone pain-but it is doable. 4 - I never stop driving(like I said though mine were every 3 wks) 5 - I never felt trapped - to me it was more like a safe haven- a good place to rest-and believe me -she'll need alot of that. I was told that during my Nadir period too stay away from crowds,but that if I had to go out use a face mask ,you know the paper ones or a scarf to cover the mouth and nose.Tell her to keep her hands wash ,that is how alot of germs are passed,going into market places and such really are full of germs ,it's better to be safe than sorry. If you get sick while going through treatments it can get serious fast because your immune system is down .Be cautious please ,and if food seems to have a metallic taste switch to plastic wear. 6 - My hair was slow to come back,it actually had little spurts of growth here and there through treatments,but it felt different.My scalp stayed tender for quite some time and it was hard to keep my head warm -it was winter time.You loose alot of heat out the top of your head ya know,I started sleeping in hats because I couldn't stand sleeping with the covers over my head LOL! Try to stay level headed,worrying doesn't really accomplish anything and only makes you feel worse.Start looking at the positive side of things to pull you up out of depression,not that there aren't going to be days that you want to cry,yell, be mad or sad and that's ok,we have to get it out of our systems,it's part of the baggage you get with the disease-so vent get rid of it-But on most days please focus on positives or things that make you happy - get out take a walk - visit a friend - go shopping- sometimes anything to get your mind away from the sickness.We have to nourish our bodies and our minds to get through this and that goes for care givers too! Sorry it ended up so long -sometimes I do go on.... Take care and God Bless You ! {{{HUGS}}}

Your Mother may feel that if she listens to the Doctor and focuses on how much time is left,it's like giving in, You know, instead of living it. Talk, laugh, cry whatever comes natural but see that You have some special time with her-You won't regret it. I just came home from being with my Sister,she has Ovarian Cancer,this is her second bout with cancer,the first was Cervical.Our Mother also died from Ovarian ,by the time it was found it had spread everywhere,that was 15 years ago.My Sister is 52 yrs old now, I hope they got all of her cancer with the surgery, she still has 3 more chemo treatments and a years worth of Taxol to do, but I thank God everyday that she is still with us. My heart goes out to You and Your Family, this is such a difficult thing to go through-it affects everyone it comes in contact with. You are all in my prayers,keep us posted. God Bless You! (((HUGS)))

Posts.Title: Expectancy of recurrance

Posts.Content: Hi, Well I have been diagnosed w/cancer,but most of us here have . Thought I'd give it a shot anyway. With a strong Family History of Cancer(different variations) I just went last week for Genetic counseling,they went ahead while I was there and drew blood for the test.The big question for me is if my insurance co will pay for the test,it's like $3000. for it .I'm sad to say most insurance companies will only pay half and I don't have that kind of money lying around,so I'm waiting on the phone to ring to find out that either it won't pay(in full) OR giving me the date that the testing is actually starting,it takes about a month.I have to say for the most part cancer is extremely expensive in its self.You lose time from work,co pays(if You are fortunate enough to have Ins.) out of pocket-deductibles and so on.Thats not to mention everything else this disease robs You of,Your health ,time w/family ,the pain and complications-it is a huge emotional roller coaster ride that no one wants to be on. Sorry to ramble,back to the subject at hand, I was told that if I tested positive I would be presented with different options. Some of those are having a comlete hysterectomy, possibly having the none diseased breast removed ,after hearing that my expression must have changed because theirs did and then they said and well we'll go over the rest if it comes back positive.I think the color must have left my face when they mention removing the other breast -that was something that just didn't enter my mind until they said it. It's alot to consider and probably the only way they would go ahead and do a hysterectomy,since I haven't had a period since Feb. of last year(due to chemo).I mean You can't just go in and say give me one Doc-Ya know. While right now I'm cancer free anything they do would be a preventative measure-and mainly due to these test results. Otherwise according to Family History my chances of dying from cancer are extremely high if I don't take preventative measures ,but then again we all have to go some how,I think when the Lord is ready to take me he will whether I think I'm ready or not ,You know. I'm glad You are cancer free and I hope You stay that way. I don't know if I've been any help ,but I've been waiting to see if someone could give You some advice or opinions on this matter-since none as of yet ,I did. Take care and keep us posted on Your testing-I'd be interested in knowing Your results. Hugs and Prayers

Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy / genetic testing

Posts.Content: So glad to hear your Mom got through this phase of her journey.Remember you can only live one day at a time there are alot of different things to cope with just try not to get overwhelmed.You will both get through this.It's a scary time for everyone-I remember thinking the same thing.Should I go through the treatments or not then I looked at my Family they were suffering right there with me,I wasn't ready to give up on life,not seeing my children through there lifes challenges or triumphs.I thought also that they may have gotten it all with surgery , but what if they didn't! And because I was scared I didn't take the treatments and it came back and took my life-I wouldn't have done all that was possible to make sure that I was here for my family .Life is short enough,it really makes you look at what's really important-and I'm not ready to give it up. It's probably not going to be easy,there are alot of unknowns,but it makes a world of difference when your family and friends are there for you-you may even find out who you're true friends really are,I know I did.But things are so much better these days than in the past.She needs to get lots of rest and a proper diet,lots of fresh untainted fruits and vegetables. Keep us posted,You all are in my prayers.
